intro: Nigella tuberculata var. saronensis, commonly known as the Armenian black cumin, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus and parts of Turkey. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its small, dark purple to black seeds that are highly aromatic. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and trifoliate leaves. Its flowers are yellow with five petals and are borne in clusters at the top of the stem. The seeds are widely used in traditional medicine and as a spice in various cuisines.
